results.title: The Good woman of Bangkok
results.creator_credit: Dennis O'Rourke and O'Rourke and Associates Filmakers
results.brief_description: This disturbing and controversial portrait of Aoi, a reluctant prostitute on the streets of Bangkok, is a very personal piece of work from filmmmaker Dennis O’Rourke. The soul of this young woman is captured as she shares her life story with the camera as much as with the filmmaker. O’Rourke picked her up in a bar and paid a pimp for her services. They stayed in a cheap motel in the red-light district. What proceeds to be laid bare, is a searing portrait of prostitution and the self-loathing that it helps breed.

results.title: Long day's journey into night
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Ely Landau, Embassy Pictures Corporation (US), Joseph E. Levine and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Eugene O’Neill’s autobiographical play is brought stunningly to the screen by director Lumet and his superb cast. Tracing the destructive interactions of an Irish-American family over a long summer’s day and night, the film is an illuminating study of familial hypocrisy and betrayal. The formidable cast includes Katherine Hepburn who dominates the screen with her portrayal of a mother addicted to morphine and unable to forgive her husband and her sons for the banality of her life, Ralph Richardson as the alcoholic father who uses his childhood experiences of poverty as a weapon against his children, Jason Robards Jr. is outstanding as the oldest son, “the failure” who has inherited his father’s alcoholism and a young Dean Stockwell is the melancholy poet, a character based on O’Neill himself. The play’s Freudian “revelations” may seem dated but the power of O’Neill’s writing is undiminished. This story of the corrosive emotional battles within a family is still shockingly relevant to a contemporary audience and so are the film’s thematic concerns with the psychological effects of migration and addiction.

results.title: Down by law
results.creator_credit: Jim Jarmusch, Alan Kleinberg, Black Snake and Grokenberger
results.brief_description: It is a sad and beautiful world that provides the setting for Jim Jarmusch’s third feature. It seems like a world of bad luck and trouble to Jack and Zack. These deadbeats may well have deserved a comeuppance, but not jail, certainly not for the long haul, and absolutely not in the same cell together. The big-talking, foolish Jack and the sullen, daydreaming Zack are mutually repellent. A new convict is pushed into their cell, an Italian tourist, Roberto. Somehow the three manage to escape and they wind up in the trackless bayou, pursued by bloodhounds. stars Tom Waits, John Lurie, Roberto Benigni and Ellen Barkin.

results.title: That Obscure object of desire = Cet obscur objet du desir
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Serge Silberman and Greenwich Film Production
results.brief_description: Mathieu (Fernando Rey) is a self-satisfied Spanish businessman whose ordered, elegant life begins to fall apart when he becomes obsessed with the virginal Conchita, who professes love for him, but refuses to have sex with him. Based on a novel by Pierre Louys, “La Femme et le Pantin”, Bunuel’s film version is a comic exploration of the libidinous energies that undermine the precarious safety and order of the bourgeoisie. Though an assured and elegant film, Bunuel utilises surrealist touches, such as having two actresses play the same lead role (Carole Bouquet and Angela Molina) to unsettle and provoke the viewer.

results.title: Conservation of artworks on paper
results.brief_description: Conservator of artworks on paper, Linda Black, demonstrates a series of conservation treatments used to slow or prevent future damage to artworks. Damage may have been caused by the use of inappropriate materials by the artist, undesirable procedures used by those preparing works for framing, or inadequate care of artworks through time. This video provides a “behind the scenes” look at the conservation operations at the Queensland Art Gallery.

results.title: Brain sex. Episode 3
results.creator_credit: Ann Moir, Cheryl Knapp, Jonathan Harris, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, Discovery Channel, Primedia Productions, Primetime Television and Quality Time TV
results.brief_description: The final program in this series looks primarily at the sexual behaviour of men and women, how it differs, and each sex’s perceptions of the opposite sex’s motivation. It also looks at more differences between the female and male brains, particularly in relation to aging, and relationships with the opposite sex.

results.title: Child care: the management challenge for the 1990's
results.creator_credit: Mark Gould, Susan Lambert and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Twenty percent of all women workers have children under five and in 56% of families with dependent children, both parents work. Inadequate childcare facilities for these working parents can result in high absenteeism, low productivity and a high turnover rate. More and more companies are seeing the advantages to providing a carefully planned work-based childcare centre which ultimately benefits not just the employees, but the employer and the children. This video provides several examples of Sydney-based companies who have taken the initiative, including the Vacation Program run jointly by the NAB, ANZ, NML and CML, the Messengers Cottage Creche for the Esso/Lend Lease employees and the Flemington Market’s proposed childcare centre. The consensus appears to be a higher retention of skilled workers, particularly women, and an overall improvement in productivity.

results.title: The Professor's new clothes
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Janet Bell, ABC-TV (Australia), Channel 4 and Film Australia
results.brief_description: ABC “Science Show” host, Robyn Williams, narrates this fascinating program on the ethics of scientific research and a recent case of major fraud involving internationally renowned geologist, Professor V. J. Gupta, of Punjab University. Gupta’s falsification of research spread over a 25 year period in 400 published papers. The fraud was unearthed due to the tireless detective work of Australian paleobiologist, Professor John Talent, of Macquarie University. The scandal generated by his findings resonated at a national level with the Indian government imposing a media ban in a cover-up attempt, but Talent’s perseverance meant the truth was finally made public.

results.title: The Boys who came home: recollections of Gallipoli
results.creator_credit: Harvey Broadbent, Paul Montgomery and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This documentary features interviews with veterans of the Gallipoli campaign. Through recollections, photographs and archival film, the history of Australia’s involvement in World war I is explored. The video includes interviews with Turkish veterans of the battle who offer their own stories of tragic loss. The documentary concludes by following a group of Australian veterans who return to the Turkish coast to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the Gallipoli campaign. The video includes footage of the official Dawn Service at Gallipoli on the 75th Anniversary of the dawn landing attended by Prime Minister Hawke.

results.title: Australians because of business
results.brief_description: A comprehensive two part program examining the successes and failures of the Australian Business Migration Program. The first part examines the history of the ABMP which was set up in the early 1980’s to entice successful entrepreneurs to Australia. Seventy percent of applicants to the ABMP were from Taiwan and Hong Kong and two years into their residency in Australia, close to half the applicants were still not involved in creating business opportunities for themselves in their new country. The second part of the program examines some of the problems encountered by business migrants including language difficulty, encountering a different commercial culture in Australia and negotiating an indifferent government bureaucracy.
